reviewText: Before watching this the "Bridge on the River Kwai" was just a war-time movie my father might have watched when I was a child.Now it is another sad tale of what happens when people go to war.What began as curiosity on the part of engineers ended  up revealing -- not only how war affects soldiers (on both sides) -- but the impact on civilians (90,000 non-military Asians died).As fascinated as I was (initially) by the building of such a structure (in such a place) the cost was simply too high.The "spoils of war" come in many forms.This (the telling of mans' unkindness to man) is one of them.

I would highly recommend it.

reviewText: The basic premise of the tape is a sound one, namely that at some point in human history a natural event of stupendous proportions took place which dramatically altered the course of events. At question is whether a volcanic explosion about 535 AD in the south pacific released enough dust into the atmosphere to lower global temperatures and trigger everything from the dramatic fall of civilizations to the outbreak of bubonic plague. That is the fundamental premise of science writer David Keys that is explored in this tape.The evidence put forward in favor of a volcanic explosion triggering a climactic change at that time is strong and convincing. Tree rings show a dramatic slowing of growth and Arctic and Antarctic ice cores show elevated levels of sulfuric acid, which indicates volcanic activity. Written evidence from the time describes events consistent with a massive volcanic eruption. While the evidence in favor of the belief that the explosion occurred at Krakatoa is only circumstantial, it is consistent with all other evidence, so it is the most likely suspect.While we all know the consequences on human history of such an explosion would be great, the evidence in favor of the precise results is much less convincing.  Keys argues that the fall of Britain to the Anglo-Saxon invaders, the outbreak of the bubonic plague, changing patterns of dominance in Asia which forced migrations to Europe, the fall of the powerful Mexican city of Teotihuacan and the rise of Islam can all be attributed to the explosion. While possible, this is all a bit too much. Civilizations rise and fall with great regularity throughout history and it is a risky proposition to attribute a movement either direction to a single natural event in a remote area, no matter how powerful it was. Nevertheless, the evidence presented is food for thought.The tape concludes with a brief description of the likelihood of similar catastrophes in the future. It is the consensus of the experts that it is not a question of if but when. According to the geological record, extremely powerful events occur regularly, and the recent explosion of Mount St. Helens shows us a glimpse of the potential power of volcanic eruptions.While I was not convinced by all Keys' arguments about the catastrophe, he never strays far from the hard evidence and I am convinced that his thesis is possible. The tape is very interesting and shows us that human history is often shaped by humans bowing to the will of nature rather than nature bowing to the will of humans.
summary: Well-organized evidence for a natural disaster

reviewText: Some thing old, some thing new, some thing analysed into some thing new.Just when you thought you had all your WWII maniacal dictators all neatly laid to rest. There pops up more declassified Russian documents, which reveal Stalin+Hilter to be even bigger pricks than you thought. These guys put the "dic" in to dictator.Claimed victories were accidents - actually near disasters.Military genius revealed as dumb luck.Germany's adventure east in to Russia was less decided by superior generals, equipment and tactics - and, ultimately determined by weather, and, the refusal by either side to back up.Still, if things had not gotten stupid in the east, there would have been a lot more Germans waiting for the allies on D-Day.
summary: An Update, of an Update, on another Review - of What We Thought We Already Knew

reviewText: Military history has fascinated me from a very young age. Within this series there are multiple episodes. Amazon allows only one review and that creates a dilemma for the reviewer. Limitations do not allow one to give information that might be helpful to others. What is the best way to present this type review? I haven't found an answer. This series was purchased but it includes some topics that are not of interest to me.Bridge on the River Kwai affords a reality not found in the Hollywood tradition of film making. Follow the interesting travels into history and marvel at human endurance. Interviews, original footage and photographs present a remarkable feat of engineering using conscript Asian labor and prisoners of war. The cruelty of the captors is undeniable. Time limits for the entire railroad would seem to present obstacles that were insurmountable. Given the availability of disposable labor it became possible.The true story of the Battle for Stalingrad is well presented with narrative, interviews and original footage. Understanding the differences in the personalities of Hitler and Stalin provide an insight within the context of WWII. What choice for those in the Soviet army: forward into German fire or retreat and be killed  by Stalin's NKGB? The Battle of Stalingrad became 'history rewritten' with the release of Soviet documents in 2000. Certainly worth watching for those with an interest in military history and an introduction for those who are beginners. Accurate and informative. Perhaps better presented in other series.

reviewText: If you enjoy probing the mysteries of history, you will enjoy Secrets of the Dead. This is an historical examination of historical events, people involved in them, and how things came to be what we read about in the history books. For example, who created the boats that landed on the beaches of Normandy during WWII?  Or who designed the "floating" tanks that landed there?  You learn about the actual events during these documentary explorations of historical events.  It is a two thumbs up effort.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The "Catasatrophe!" that is the focus of this first volume in the "Secrets of the Dead" series is a cataclysmic event that some scientists believed occurred around 535 A.D.  Apparently, the early Dark Ages were called that for a reason: a natural disaster literally reduced the amount of sunshine.  The starting point for this scientific inquiry are the record of tree rings from the period that show abnormally small growth rates for several years during that time span.  Focusing primarily on the work of science writer David Keys, this documentary eliminates extraterrestrial sources (asteroids, comets, etc.) for this natural disaster and searches for a volcanic explosion as the triggering device.  However, that becomes only the first half of this endeavor as the case is then made for the significant effects this catastrophe had for human civilization.  Viewers will be fascinated to learn that the Mongol invasion of Europe, the rise of the bubonic plague, the fall of the great Mexican city of Teotihuacan, the victory of the Anglo-Saxons over the Celts, and even the rise of Islam can be linked to the massive volcanic explosion.The strength of "Catastrophe!", which is narrated by actor Roy Scheider, is the chain of scientific reasoning it lays out for the audience, both in determining what happened and in laying out the case for the specific results this particular volcanic explosion caused in human history.  However, at two hours in length it is a bit overlong and I think the documentary could have benefitted from some better editing to help pick up the pace (I would think PBS would not have a big problem with the 90 minute format, but maybe that was problematic in 2000 with regards to this series).  Still, this videotape should prove most instructive in the classroom since it provides a detailed case study of how scientists and historians arrive at their conclusions.  Whatever the specific case study at hand, that is a lesson well worth the learning.
summary: A fascinating hypothesis on what caused the "Dark Ages"

reviewText: I find all the films from this series very interesting.  I jump around on the choices in the series from my Amazon Instant and watch the one that catches my interest.  I will probably end up watching all that are available on Instant.  I have seen 7 so far.  There have been 55 episodes of this PBS series running from May 2000 to now.  All the ones that I have viewed contain video and pictures from the era that is covered in the story along with detailed narration analysis.  There are interviews from people still alive that add to the interest and appeal to the sometimes terrible events and to the pure history.  I recommend viewing all of these shows that Instant has available.  These are great documentaries.
summary: This film concerns the "Bridge over the River Kwai" episode first shown on PBS in 11/12/2003.

reviewText: Secrets of the Dead is an intriguing series as it explores events that occurred in the past ,recreating  historical happenings around the world, and providing fact-based explanations. One of my favorite episodes is the episode titled Escape from Auschwitz which recounts how two inmates at the Auschwitz concentration/ extermination camp managed to escape the camp and fulfill their mission - that is to inform the world about the atrocities occurring in the camp, i.e. the systematic murder of European Jewry (and others, including gypsies) through gassing and other deliberate means. It is a horrific tale, and quite disturbing.The show also features interviews with survivors of Auschwitz who provide first-hand accounts of some of the atrocities committed there, as well as interviews with an academic who provides detailed information on the men, Rudolph Vrba and Alfred Wetzler, who managed the impossible - to escape in the hope of telling the world what they had witnessed in Auschwitz.This is recommended viewing for those who appreciate quality documentaries that explore the past, especially significant historical events.
Title: N/A
